As part of the course, there are several articles, papers and technical reports that you will need to read during the semester. Most of the articles themselves are accessible through the University of Minnesota library website (http://www.lib.umn.edu). In order to access the full text of some of the articles, you will need to log in using your University x500 username and password. More detailed information, including references or links to specific readings, are given below.


# Welcome to EPsy 8252 {#welcome}

**Required**

Download and read through the course syllabus.

- [Course Syllabus](https://github.com/zief0002/epsy-8252/raw/master/syllabus/s20-8252-syllabus.pdf) [pdf]


Download and install R and RStudio:

- Download R from the [R Project website](https://www.r-project.org/) and install it on your computer.
- Download the free version of RStudio from the [RStudio website](https://www.rstudio.com/) and install it on your computer.

---


# Introduction to RMarkdown {#rmarkdown}

**Required**

- Download the [sample BibTeX file](https://github.com/zief0002/epsy-8252/raw/master/notes/01-rmarkdown/myBibliography.bib)
- Download the CSL style file for the [American Psychological Association 7th edition (single-spaced bibliography)](https://www.zotero.org/styles). Make sure you save this so that it has the *.csl* extension.
- Install the R package **tinytex**. This package will allow you to compile to PDF. Once you have the package installed run `tinytex::install_tinytex()` in the RStudio Console. You can read more of the [documentation here](https://yihui.name/tinytex/). 

<br />

Read the following:

- [Unit 01: Introduction to RMarkdown Notes](https://github.com/zief0002/epsy-8252/raw/master/notes/01-rmarkdown/01-rmarkdown.pdf)


**Additional Resources**

In addition to the notes and what we cover in class, there many other resources for learning about R Markdown. Here are some resources that may be helpful in that endeavor:

- [Rmarkdown (and friends) Tutorial](http://www.flutterbys.com.au/stats/tut/tut17.5.html#h2_1)
- [Getting Started with RMarkdown](https://ourcodingclub.github.io/2016/11/24/rmarkdown-1.html)
- [R Markdown documentation:](http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com/) Official R Markdown documentation from RStudio
- [R Markdown cheatsheet:](https://www.rstudio.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/rmarkdown-cheatsheet.pdf) What it sounds like; a cheatsheet for R Markdown
- [knitr:](http://yihui.name/knitr/) Document and code chunk options for R Markdown
- [R Markdown Gallery:](https://rmarkdown.rstudio.com/gallery.html) - Gallery of some R Markdown outputs
- [Pimp my Rmd:](https://holtzy.github.io/Pimp-my-rmd/) Blog post providing a few tips to improve the appearance of output documents.

# Polynomial Regression {#polynomial}

**Required**

- Refresh your knowledge about parabolas and quadratic functions by going though the [Khan Academy Parabolas Intro](https://www.khanacademy.org/math/algebra-home/alg-quadratics)


**Additional Resources**

In addition to the notes and what we cover in class, there are many other resources for learning about polynomial functions. Here are some resources that may be helpful in that endeavor:

- [Varsity Tutors: Quadratic Function](https://www.varsitytutors.com/hotmath/hotmath_help/topics/quadratic-function)
- [Math Centre: Polynomial Function](http://www.mathcentre.ac.uk/resources/uploaded/mc-ty-polynomial-2009-1.pdf)
- [Overfitting: A guided tour](https://www.alexpghayes.com/blog/overfitting-a-guided-tour/)

# Log-Transforming the Outcome {#logoutcome}

**Required**

Read the following:

- Osborne, Jason (2002). [Notes on the use of data transformations](https://pareonline.net/getvn.asp?v=8&n=6). *Practical Assessment, Research &amp; Evaluation, 8*(6).


**Additional Resources**

In addition to the notes and what we cover in class, there are many other resources for learning about log-transformations. Here are some resources that may be helpful in that endeavor:

- [UCLA IDRE: Interpreting Log-Transformed Variables in Regression ](https://stats.idre.ucla.edu/other/mult-pkg/faq/general/faqhow-do-i-interpret-a-regression-model-when-some-variables-are-log-transformed/)
- [Interpret Regression Coefficient Estimates](http://www.cazaar.com/ta/econ113/interpreting-beta)

# Probability Distributions {#probdist}

**Required**

Read the following:

- Fox (Section 3.1.1) *Probability Basics* [Required Textbook] 
- Fox (Sections 3.3.1&ndash;3.3.4)*Continuous Distributions* [Required Textbook]
- Refresh your knowledge about probability distributions by going though the [Kahn Academy: Random Variables and Probability Distributions](https://www.khanacademy.org/math/probability/random-variables-topic) tutorial.


**Additional Resources**

In addition to the notes and what we cover in class, there are many other resources for learning about probability distributions. Here are some resources that may be helpful in that endeavor:

- [Common probability distributions: The data scientist's cribsheet](https://medium.com/@srowen/common-probability-distributions-347e6b945ce4)
- Leemis, L. M., &amp; McQueston, J. T. (2008). [Univariate distribution relationships.](http://www.stat.rice.edu/~dobelman/courses/texts/leemis.distributions.2008amstat.pdf) *The American Statistician, 62*(1), 45&ndash;53.
- Leemis, L. M. (n.d.) [Univariate distribution relationships: Interactive website.](http://www.math.wm.edu/~leemis/chart/UDR/UDR.html)

# Information Criteria for Model Selection {#infcrit}

**Required**

Read up to the *Multimodel Inference* section in the following:

- Burnham, K. P., Anderson, D. R., &amp; Huyvaert, K. P. (2010). [AIC model selection and multimodel inference in behavioral ecology: Some background, observations, and comparisons](https://link-springer-com.ezp3.lib.umn.edu/article/10.1007/s00265-010-1029-6). *Behavioral Ecology and Sociobiology, 65*(1), 23&ndash;35.


**Additional Resources**

In addition to the notes and what we cover in class, there are many other resources for learning about information criteria. Here are some resources that may be helpful in that endeavor:

- Anderson, David R. (2008). [Model based inference in the life sciences: A primer on evidence](https://link-springer-com.ezp3.lib.umn.edu/book/10.1007%2F978-0-387-74075-1). New York: Springer.
- Burnham, Kenneth P., &amp; Anderson, David R. (2002). [Model selection and multimodel inference: A practical information-theoretic approach](http://ecologia.ib.usp.br/bie5782/lib/exe/fetch.php?media=bie5782:pdfs:burnham_anderson2002.pdf). New York: Springer.

# Cross-Sectional Linear Mixed-Effects Models {#lmer-cross}

**Required**

Before class you will need to read:

- Hayes, A. F. (2006). [A primer on multilevel modeling.](http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1468-2958.2006.00281.x/abstract) *Human Communication Research, 32*(4), 385&ndash;410.

Focus on the information on mutating joins.


**Additional Resources**

In addition to the notes and what we cover in class, there are many other resources for learning about using linear mixed-effects models for cross-sectional analysis. Here are some resources that may be helpful in that endeavor:

- Hofmann, D. A., & Gavin, M. B. (1998). [Centering decisions in hierarchical linear models: Implications for research in organizations](https://primo.lib.umn.edu/primo-explore/fulldisplay?docid=TN_sciversesciencedirect_elsevierS0149-2063(99)80077-4&context=PC&vid=TWINCITIES&search_scope=mncat_discovery&tab=article_discovery&lang=en_US). *Journal of Management, 24*(5), 623&ndash;641.
- Scherbaum, C. A., & Ferreter, J. M. (2009). [Estimating statistical power and required sample sizes for organizational research using multilevel modeling](https://journals-sagepub-com.ezp2.lib.umn.edu/doi/pdf/10.1177/1094428107308906). *Organizational Research Methods, 12*(2), 347&ndash;367.


For **table formatting** using R Markdown, check out:

- [Stargazer for lmer Models](http://svmiller.com/blog/2015/02/quasi-automating-the-inclusion-of-random-effects-in-rs-stargazer-package/)


If you are interested in the estimation of the coefficients, see:

- [Estimation of the Log-Likelihood in lmer](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/20980116/how-does-lmer-from-the-r-package-lme4-compute-log-likelihood)

Before class you will need to read:
